results.title: The Chalice
results.creator_credit: Ultramedia Productions, Bryant Ewing and Shevard Goldstein
results.brief_description: Set in some affluent, edwardian part of the United States, a father congratulates his son on graduating from Harvard. The father soberly points out to the son that a certain tradition must follow, a tradition dating back through the family, a tradition dating back to Sir Charles. The son must drink from a chalice.. This short film is a forgotten masterpiece of climax comedy. Written by L.James Herbert and edited by Gregory Pike.

results.title: The Chain Reaction
results.creator_credit: Palm Beach Pictures, Ross Matthews and Ian Barry
results.brief_description: A thriller in which a married couple are thrown into a world of terror, after being contaminated with radioactivity. Cast includes Steve Bisley, Hugh Keays-Byrne, Lorna Lesley. Photography by Nixon Binney.

results.title: The Chain gang
results.creator_credit: English, Scottish and Australian Bank Film Unit and A Zegenhagen
results.brief_description: Training film for bank tellers, aiming to foster customer loyalty by making the customer feel welcome, important and at ease. The chain of branches is 500 strong and each individual bank throughout Australia is important as a link in the chain. Personal attention is shown to be vital in the formation of the customer’s image of the bank.

results.title: The Centre
results.creator_credit: Films of Fact, Paul Rotha and J.B. Holmes
results.brief_description: The Pioneer Health Centre in Peckham was one of the first community health centres in England. This film shows the facilities and follows a family who join the Centre. The father and young son enjoy the Centre’s activities, however, the mother is less impressed because the Centre’s thorough medical check revealed that she needs to undergo surgery. The mother is gradually won over as she regains her health through the Centre’s facilities.

results.title: The Centre
results.brief_description: A promotional film of Alice Springs and environs, covering its services, facilities and tourist features. Includes footage on Uluru (Ayers Rock). Narrated by John Laws.

results.title: The Centigram beam balance
results.brief_description: Instructional film showing: use of measuring instruments; preparation of balance for use; levelling and adjusting the beam; use of weights; technique of weighing; checking the weight; packing up weight and closing the balance case.

results.title: The Centenary test
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Brian Harvey
results.brief_description: This film consists of highlights from the 1977 Centenary Test Match played at the Melbourne Cricket Ground, March 12th-17th, between Australia and England. It contains interviews by Richie Benaud with former and current players of both teams and commentators include Norman May, Frank Tyson, Jim Laker, Keith Miller and Paul Sheahan.

results.title: The Cemetery of the elephants
results.creator_credit: Producciones Cinematograficas Nacionales, Films Incorporated, Mario Vasquez and Armando Robles Godoy
results.brief_description: An allegorical story about a young writer who leaves home with his manuscript determined to conquer the world, then returns home after years of struggle as an old man with the world still unconquered. Non-narrated. Suitable for middle secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Producciones Cinematograficas Nacionales, Films Incorporated, Mario Vasquez and Armando Robles Godoy

results.title: The Celluloid heroes: 1896-1996 Celebrating 100 years of Australian Cinema. - Vol. 2.
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia, Anthony Buckley, Donald Crombie and Robert Francis
results.brief_description: Episode 3: Arising from the ashes. 1949-1970. The post-war film world was dominated by Hollywood giants but local heroes achieved huge success in “Smiley” and “Jedda” with stars like Chips Rafferty and Bud Tingwell. This episode explores the influences which encouraged success in the Australian film industry and overviews Australian life during the Menzies era and ‘60’s - the point where the industry gained a financial footing for the first time in decades. Episode 4: Beyond our wildest dreams. 1971-1995. The era when our cinema was reborn with the classics “Picnic at hanging rock”, The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith”, “Mad Max”, “Breaker Morant” and “Gallipoli. This renaissance fostered the talents of Mel Gibson, Judy Davis and the directors Peter Weir, Gillian Armstrong, George Miller and Bruce Beresford. Australia’s image internationally consolidated with “Crocodile Dundee”, Strictly Ballroom”, “The Adventures of Priscilla Queen of the Desert and “Muriel’s Wedding”. Within 25 years the film industry had moved from near extinction to a point beyond our wildest dreams. Narrated by Bryan Brown.

results.title: The Celluloid heroes: 1896-1996 Celebrating 100 years of Australian Cinema. - Vol. 1.
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia, Anthony Buckley and Robert Francis
results.brief_description: Episode 1: The Pioneers. 1894-1927. Australians of the 1890’s were among the first to discover the film medium, producing a dynamic band of film-makers with a bold and uncompromising vision. Raymond Longford, Lottie Lyall and Beau Smith fought against incredible odds and produced classics like “The Story of the Kelly Gang”, “Robbery under Arms”, “The Squatters Daughter” and the internationally acclaimed “The Sentimental Bloke.” Episode 2: “O.K. for Sound” 1928-1948. The new technology of talking pictures revolutionised the film industry and created new stars. “In the Wake of the Bounty” introduced Errol Flynn. This was the era of the Dad and Dave films and masterpieces such as Charles Chauvel’s “Forty Thousand Horseman.” Australia’s documentary tradition continued with classics like “Journey of a Nation” and “Kokoda Front Line.” Narrated by Bryan Brown.
